Exploring the World of Robux Generators: Unlocking the Secrets to Free Virtual Currency

In the captivating world of online gaming, Roblox has carved out a unique niche, captivating millions of players worldwide with its endless possibilities for creativity and adventure. At the heart of this vibrant community lies Robux, the virtual currency that fuels the Roblox experience. As players seek to unlock new experiences, acquire coveted in-game items, and elevate their gaming prowess, the demand for Robux has never been higher.

However, the cost of Robux can often be a barrier for many players, leading them to explore alternative methods of obtaining this valuable resource. Enter the world of Robux generators â€“ platforms that claim to provide free or discounted Robux, seemingly bypassing the need for traditional purchases. But are these generators truly legitimate, and what are the risks associated with their use?

Unraveling the Mysteries of Robux Generators
Robux generators are online tools or applications that promise to generate or provide free Robux for Roblox players. These platforms often claim to exploit vulnerabilities or loopholes in the Roblox system, allowing users to bypass the need to purchase Robux directly from the platform.

The allure of free virtual currency is undeniable, and many players are tempted to explore these generators in the hopes of gaining an advantage in their Roblox adventures. However, the reality is far more complex than it may initially appear.

The Risks of Robux Generators
While the promise of free Robux may seem enticing, the use of Robux generators is fraught with risk. These platforms are often fronts for scams, designed to exploit unsuspecting players and compromise their personal information or accounts.

One of the primary concerns with Robux generators is the potential for malware or viruses to be embedded within the software or websites. By downloading or interacting with these generators, users may unknowingly expose their devices to harmful code that can steal sensitive data, compromise their online security, or even hold their systems for ransom.

Additionally, many Robux generators are simply not legitimate, and any "Robux" obtained through these means will ultimately be worthless. Roblox has a sophisticated anti-cheating system in place, and the use of unauthorized generators can result in bans, account suspensions, or even the loss of legitimate Robux purchases.

The Consequences of Using Robux Generators
The consequences of using Robux generators can be severe and far-reaching. Beyond the immediate risks of malware and account compromise, the use of these platforms can have long-term repercussions for Roblox players.

Roblox takes a strong stance against the use of unauthorized generators, and any accounts found to be using them may be subject to permanent bans or suspensions. This not only prevents players from accessing their Roblox accounts and the associated content, but it can also tarnish their reputation within the community, making it difficult to regain trust and participate fully in the platform.

Moreover, the use of Robux generators can undermine the Roblox economy and the overall gaming experience for all players. By introducing fraudulent Robux into the system, these generators can devalue the virtual currency, disrupting the balance of the in-game marketplace and affecting the experiences of honest players.

The Legitimate Path to Obtaining Robux
Rather than risking their accounts and security by using Robux generators, players are encouraged to explore the legitimate methods of obtaining Robux within the Roblox ecosystem. This includes purchasing Robux directly from the Roblox platform, earning Robux through participation in the Roblox Developer Exchange program, or engaging in various in-game activities and challenges that reward Robux.

By embracing the official Roblox ecosystem, players can ensure the integrity of their accounts, contribute to the growth and sustainability of the platform, and enjoy a secure and fulfilling gaming experience.

Conclusion
The allure of free Robux may be tempting, but the risks associated with Robux generators far outweigh any potential benefits. By understanding the dangers of these unauthorized platforms and committing to the legitimate methods of acquiring Robux, Roblox players can safeguard their accounts, protect their personal information, and contribute to the overall health and vitality of the Roblox community.

Getting Robux for Free: Unlocking the Secrets

In the world of Roblox, Robux are the virtual currency that allows players to unlock new experiences, purchase in-game items, and enhance their gaming journey. While Robux can be acquired through various means, such as purchasing them with real money, many Roblox enthusiasts are searching for ways to obtain Robux for free. In this comprehensive guide, we'll explore the legitimate and effective methods to get Robux without spending a dime.

Participate in Roblox Surveys and Offers
One of the most straightforward ways to earn Robux for free is by participating in various surveys and offers provided by Roblox. These opportunities are often presented through the Roblox website or third-party platforms that partner with the game. By completing these surveys or offers, you can earn Robux that can be directly added to your account. It's important to note that the amount of Robux earned may vary, and some offers may require you to provide personal information or complete specific tasks, so it's crucial to exercise caution and only participate in legitimate and trustworthy opportunities.

Join Roblox Affiliate Programs
Another way to earn Robux for free is by becoming a Roblox Affiliate. Roblox offers an affiliate program that allows content creators, such as YouTubers, bloggers, and social media influencers, to earn Robux by promoting the game and its in-game items to their audience. By creating engaging content that showcases Roblox and its features, affiliates can earn a commission for every new player they refer to the platform. This not only provides a reliable way to earn Robux but also allows you to share your passion for Roblox with your followers.

Participate in Roblox Contests and Events
Roblox frequently organizes various contests and events where players can win Robux as prizes. These opportunities range from creative building challenges to community-driven initiatives. By keeping an eye on the Roblox blog and social media channels, you can stay informed about upcoming contests and events, and participate in them for a chance to earn free Robux. Winning these contests not only adds Robux to your account but also provides a sense of accomplishment and recognition within the Roblox community.

Earn Robux through the Roblox Developer Exchange Program
If you have a knack for game development and creativity, you can consider becoming a Roblox developer. The Roblox Developer Exchange Program allows developers to earn Robux by creating and publishing their own games on the platform. As your games gain popularity and generate revenue, you can exchange the earned Robux for real-world currency, effectively turning your passion for game development into a source of free Robux.

Utilize Roblox Promo Codes
Roblox occasionally releases promo codes that can be redeemed for free Robux or other in-game items. These promo codes are often shared on the Roblox social media channels, forums, and various fan communities. By staying up-to-date with the latest Roblox news and actively searching for valid promo codes, you can add Robux to your account without any cost.

Avoid Scams and Untrustworthy Websites
While the methods mentioned above are legitimate ways to earn free Robux, it's important to be cautious of any websites or platforms that claim to offer "free Robux generators" or "Robux hacks." These are often scams designed to steal your personal information or infect your device with malware. Stick to the official Roblox channels and reputable third-party platforms to ensure the safety and legitimacy of your Robux-earning efforts.

In conclusion, there are several effective and legitimate ways to get Robux for free on Roblox. By participating in surveys and offers, joining affiliate programs, winning contests, becoming a developer, and utilizing promo codes, you can enhance your Roblox experience without having to spend any real money. Remember to always exercise caution, stay informed, and engage with the Roblox community to maximize your chances of earning free Robux.

Unlocking the Secrets of Free Robux: A Comprehensive Guide

In the vibrant world of Roblox, where creativity knows no bounds, the pursuit of virtual currency, Robux, is a common endeavor among gamers. While Robux can be acquired through various means, the allure of obtaining them for free is a temptation that many find irresistible. In this article, we'll explore the ins and outs of free Robux codes, delving into the legalities, potential risks, and legitimate methods to help you maximize your Roblox experience without breaking the bank.

Understanding the Legality of Free Robux Codes
The topic of free Robux codes can be a minefield of misinformation and potential legal pitfalls. It's important to understand that Roblox, the platform responsible for creating and managing Robux, does not officially endorse or provide any free Robux codes. Any claims of free Robux codes or generators are likely to be scams or malicious attempts to compromise your account security. It's crucial to exercise caution and stick to legitimate methods approved by Roblox to earn Robux.

Avoiding the Risks of Free Robux Scams
The internet is rife with websites and individuals peddling "free Robux" offers, but these are almost always nothing more than elaborate scams. These scams can take various forms, such as requiring you to complete surveys, share personal information, or even download malware-infested files. By falling for these traps, you risk compromising the security of your Roblox account, exposing yourself to identity theft, or even experiencing financial losses.

Legitimate Ways to Earn Free Robux
While the promise of free Robux may seem enticing, the reality is that Roblox has designed its platform to encourage players to earn Robux through legitimate means. Here are some of the most effective and approved methods to acquire Robux without resorting to questionable tactics:

1. Participate in Roblox Tutorials and Quests: Roblox offers a variety of tutorials and quests that players can complete to earn Robux. These tasks are designed to help new users navigate the platform and can be a reliable source of free Robux.

2. Sell Virtual Items in the Roblox Marketplace: As a Roblox user, you have the opportunity to create and sell virtual items, such as accessories, clothing, or game passes, within the platform's marketplace. The revenue generated from these sales can be used to purchase Robux.

3. Engage in Roblox Affiliate Programs: Roblox has an official affiliate program that allows creators and influencers to earn Robux by promoting the platform and its features to their audience. By becoming a Roblox affiliate, you can earn Robux through referrals and shared revenue.

4. Participate in Roblox Competitions and Events: Roblox regularly hosts competitions, contests, and events that offer Robux as prizes. By showcasing your creativity, game development skills, or community involvement, you can increase your chances of earning free Robux.

5. Earn Robux through Roblox Game Development: For those with a knack for game development, Roblox offers the opportunity to create and publish your own games on the platform. As your games gain popularity and generate revenue, you can earn Robux through the platform's revenue-sharing system.

Conclusion
The pursuit of free Robux can be a tempting endeavor, but it's crucial to navigate this landscape with caution and an understanding of the potential risks involved. Issues.Title: refactor(@angular-devkit/schematics): avoid double file access reading JSON files
Issues.Body: The file system engine hosts for schematics were using a helper method to read JSON files that was performing both an exist and read call. Besides causing two file system calls, this also has a potential race condition where the file may not exist by the time the read call is made. To avoid this, a try/catch is used with the read call to handle the not existing case.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(@angular-devkit/schematics): avoid double file access reading JSON files" (#27928)

### Command

build

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

After upgrading to angular 18 and the new build system, the output main.js file no longer contains environment variables. 

My environment.prod.ts file looks like this:

export const environment = {
  production: true,
  aadClientId: '{#Config:Op.Front.MyApp:AzureAd:ClientId#}',
  // more variables here
  }

and the deployment pipeline in azure would search in main.xxx.js to replace placeholders with appropriate values based on environment (dev, staging, prod)

however with the new angular build system, the generated main file ( for example browser/main-Y276RYOS.js')  no longer contains the placeholder. 

Why is that ? Is there a way to keep the old behavior ? Otherwise my deployment pipeline in azure just doesn't work anymore and I'm not sure how to refactor this ..

steps are described above in description

_No response_

#### Using Bzlmod with Bazel 6:

1.  Enable with `common --enable_bzlmod` in `.bazelrc`.
2.  Add to your `MODULE.bazel` file:

```starlark
bazel_dep(name = "aspect_bazel_lib", version = "2.7.8")
```

> Read more about bzlmod: <https://blog.aspect.dev/bzlmod>

#### Using WORKSPACE

Paste this snippet into your `WORKSPACE` file:

```starlark
load("@​bazel_tools//tools/build_defs/repo:http.bzl", "http_archive")

http_archive(
    name = "aspect_bazel_lib",
    sha256 = "714cf8ce95a198bab0a6a3adaffea99e929d2f01bf6d4a59a2e6d6af72b4818c",
    strip_prefix = "bazel-lib-2.7.8",
    url = "https://github.com/aspect-build/bazel-lib/releases/download/v2.7.8/bazel-lib-v2.7.8.tar.gz",
)

load("@​aspect_bazel_lib//lib:repositories.bzl", "aspect_bazel_lib_dependencies", "aspect_bazel_lib_register_toolchains")

### Required bazel-lib dependencies

aspect_bazel_lib_dependencies()

### Register bazel-lib toolchains

aspect_bazel_lib_register_toolchains()

```

#### What's Changed

-   chore: upgrade to Aspect Workflows 5.10.0-rc1 by [@​gregmagolan](https://togithub.com/gregmagolan) in [https://github.com/aspect-build/bazel-lib/pull/861](https://togithub.com/aspect-build/bazel-lib/pull/861)

-   chore: add --check_direct_dependencies to .bazelrc by [@​gregmagolan](https://togithub.com/gregmagolan) in [https://github.com/aspect-build/bazel-lib/pull/864](https://togithub.com/aspect-build/bazel-lib/pull/864)

Issues.Title: Angular 17: Compiling with Angular sources in Ivy partial compilation mode. An unhandled exception occurred: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
Issues.Body:
### Command

build

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

16.0.0

### Description

After updating angular deps to version 17.0.9, the build is failing with the following error in the Jenkins build: 
Compiling with Angular sources in Ivy partial compilation mode. An unhandled exception occurred: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name').

### Minimal Reproduction

Update the following dependencies: 

"dependencies": {
     "@angular-devkit/core": "17.0.9",
    "@angular/animation": "^4.0.0-beta.8",
    "@angular/animations": "17.0.9",
    "@angular/cdk": "~17.3.0",
    "@angular/common": "17.0.9",
    "@angular/compiler": "17.0.9",

    "@angular/core": "17.0.9",
    "@angular/forms": "^17.3.11",
    "@angular/localize": "~17.3.0",
    "@angular/material": "17.0.5",
    "@angular/platform-browser": "^17.3.11",
    "@angular/platform-browser-dynamic": "17.0.9",
    "@angular/router": "^17.3.11",
    "@ngtools/webpack": "17.0.9",
}

"devDependencies": {
    "@angular-devkit/build-angular": "17.0.9",
    "@angular-devkit/build-ng-packagr": "~0.1002.0",
    "@angular/cli": "17.0.9",
    "@angular/compiler-cli": "^17.0.9",
    "@angular/language-service": "^17.3.11",
    // additional dependencies
}



### Exception or Error

```text
- Compiling with Angular sources in Ivy partial compilation mode.
âœ– Compiling with Angular sources in Ivy partial compilation mode.
An unhandled exception occurred: Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'name')
See "/tmp/ng-xlgoLw/angular-errors.log" for further details.
```


### Your Environment

```text
Angular: 17.0.9
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core
... platform-browser-dynamic

Package                            Version
------------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect          0.1700.9
```

Issues.Title: refactor(@angular/cli): use non-experimental decorators for internal memoize
Issues.Body: With standard decorator support now available for use, the memoize decorator has been updated to be a standard decorator instead of the TypeScript experimental decorator. This change also removes the only usage of decorators within the Angular CLI code itself. This change does not affect application code.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "refactor(@angular/cli): use non-experimental decorators for internal memoize" (#27913)

Issues.Title: build: additional fixes for tsetse rule compliance
Issues.Body: Due to bazel rules_nodejs caching, several additional `JSON.parse` usages were not caught in the first set of fixes. These have now been addressed. Also, the `must-use-promises` rule has been patched to match the behavior of the `@typescript-eslint/no-floating-promises` for consistency.

Issues.Title: Angular 17 with esbuild and JIT compilation have obfuscated stacktraces
Issues.Body:
### Command

serve

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

angular 17.x with latest webpack

### Description

Since we update from webpack builder to esbuild, the error raced when a service is injected without being provided first does not show the service name. It's very annoying as it can be very painful to find out which service is missing in a very big application.

The stacktrace given with esbuild
![esbuild_provider_stacktrace](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/assets/12464776/33a741a9-9a68-48a6-b9d3-ab5cafd8ca3e)

The stacktrace given with webpack
![webpack_provider_stacktrace](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/assets/12464776/5fca3389-cfb3-4608-8c01-79c3e46d5cb1)


### Minimal Reproduction

Here is a minimal reproduction project https://github.com/padoa/angular_esbuild_example. You just have to serve the application using `yarn serve` or `yarn serve:webpack` and then click on one of the two buttons to see the error raced in the console.

### Exception or Error

_No response_

### Your Environment

```text
~/angular_esbuild_example $> ng version

Angular CLI: 17.3.8
Node: 18.18.0
Package Manager: npm 9.8.1
OS: darwin arm64

Angular: 17.3.11
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1703.8
@angular-devkit/build-angular   17.3.8
@angular-devkit/core            17.3.8
@angular-devkit/schematics      17.3.8
@angular/cli                    17.3.8
@schematics/angular             17.3.8
rxjs                            7.8.1
typescript                      5.4.5
zone.js                         0.14.7
```


### Anything else relevant?

We found out that the following issue (https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/55304) was incriminating  the standalone API, so in the reproduction project we implemented both NgModule and Standalone but still the error is obfuscated.
Also, using AOT compilation instead of JIT in development resolves this issue. Is there any reason why JIT compilation with esbuild does not show the class name in stacktraces ?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Angular 17 with esbuild and JIT compilation have obfuscated stacktraces" (#27919)

Issues.Title: application-builder: Error when route ends with filename
Issues.Body:
### Command

serve

### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

Using webpack (browser builder)

### Description

If a route in the Angular app has a path parameter at the end of the route and the parameter ends with a known file-ending (e.g. json, pdf, jpg, png, etc.), vite throws an error saying "Cannot GET (route)".

## Example
Assume this routing config:
```
{
    path: 'test/:id',
    component: TestComponent
}
```

http://localhost:4200/test/myfile.jpg -> errors
http://localhost:4200/test/myfile.pdf -> errors
http://localhost:4200/test/myfile.jpga -> works, parameter is handed to component and component is properly rendered
http://localhost:4200/test/myfile -> works too

### Minimal Reproduction

https://github.com/laurenzfiala/ng-app-builder-repro

How to test:
1. serve the app
2. open http://localhost:4200/test/mycustomid -> this works as expected
3. open http://localhost:4200/test/mycustomid.jpg -> the page shows "Cannot GET /test/mycustomid.jpg"

To me this is very unexpected, especially since it worked before migrating to vite. I would expect the parameter to have the value "mycustomid.jpg" and the component to be rendered properly.

### Exception or Error

_No response_

```text
Angular CLI: 18.0.5
Node: 20.13.1
```

Issues.Title: build: enabled isolated modules TypeScript option
Issues.Body: The TypeScript `isolatedModules` option is now enabled for all TypeScript code within the repository. As a result, all packages will now be built with the option enabled. This does not affect projects created with the CLI and is only related to the building of the actual Angular CLI code. The `isolatedModules` option ensures that code can be emitted without the TypeScript typechecker and allows tools other than TypeScript to potentially be used. Code was updated to correct all errors after the option was enabled. Additionally, some early code fixes were done to add function and accessor return types to prepare for future `isolatedDeclarations` usage. More changes would be needed to consider turning on `isolatedDeclarations`, however.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "build: enabled isolated modules TypeScript option" (#27908)

Issues.Title: Custom builders using @angular-devkit/build-angular cannot resolve downstream packages when compiled using tsc
Issues.Body:
### Command

other

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

17.3

### Description

We have a custom builder for our angular project that has worked smoothly since Angular 8. We recently upgraded from Angular 15 to Angular 18 and tsc now throws errors when attempting to compile the builder. The errors thrown suggest changing the "moduleResolution" setting in tsconfig.builders.json, but each setting results in different downstream module resolution problems in the @angular-devkit/build-angular package.

Example error:

Issues.Title: bug(button): FAB Button without elevation
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

We cannot use FAB button without elevation.

Navigation Rail in MD3 supports an FAB button in the top, but doesn't require elevation.

https://m3.material.io/components/navigation-rail/guidelines

If we try to remove the elevation, after clicking the button, the elevation reappers.

```
.mat-mdc-fab {
  box-shadow: none;
  &:hover {
    box-shadow: none;
  }
}
```


[Since this PR](https://github.com/angular/components/issues/28618) we can use the elevation helpers in v18.

I'd sugest removing the elevation, and let the user chooses when to apply it... but this, will probably break many apps/tests.
Perhaps an input option to remove it?

You can check an example in the MD3 site.

![image](https://github.com/angular/components/assets/12090931/b3e13c43-3c10-48e8-ab46-90be4f23fa99)

### Reproduction

https://material.angular.io/components/button/examples

### Expected Behavior

FAB shouldn't have elevation by default.

### Actual Behavior

We are unable to remove elevation from a FAB button.

### Environment

- Angular: 18
- CDK/Material: 18
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "bug(button): FAB Button without elevation" (#29310)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-button-toggle): Disabled buttons are not ignored in radio pattern interaction for single select
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

After the implementation of the keyboard interaction in v18 (#28548) we spotted a small issue with the behavior when there are disabled buttons in the `mat-button-toggle-group`. While navigating the selection in the group via keyboard, the selection can move into the disabled buttons and then stops, preventing the navigation to the rest of the items after the disabled button. Also, visually it looks like both disabled and the previous button are highlighted.

![image](https://github.com/angular/components/assets/21110003/00231057-b1e6-442d-b607-f5413a07dbbe)

### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/ywl3wm-hddgcz?file=src%2Fexample%2Fbutton-toggle-overview-example.html
Steps to reproduce:
1. Open the example [provided in Stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/ywl3wm-hddgcz?file=src%2Fexample%2Fbutton-toggle-overview-example.html)
2. Set the focus on the mat-button-toggle component. (e.g. Press tab until you reach it, or simply click on the first item)
3. Use the arrow keys (either left/right or up/down) to navigate through the items.
4. Observe that the disabled button receives focus and gets selected.

Extra notes:
While the selection is on the disabled item, if you hit Space or Enter the selection will move back to the previous active item.

### Expected Behavior

By using the arrow keys, the selection should rotate around the active buttons and ignore the disabled ones.

### Actual Behavior

The selection allows selecting a disabled button, and once selected, it cannot move the selection further. When attempting to move back, the selection jumps over one item.

### Environment

- Angular: 18.0.4
- CDK/Material: 18.0.4
- Browser(s): Firefox, Chrome, Safari
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows, MacOS

```
Angular CLI: 18.0.5
Node: 18.20.3
Package Manager: yarn 1.22.19
OS: linux x64

Angular: 18.0.4
... animations, cdk, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... localize, material, material-experimental
... material-moment-adapter, platform-browser
... platform-browser-dynamic, router

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1800.5
@angular-devkit/build-angular   18.0.5
@angular-devkit/core            18.0.5
@angular-devkit/schematics      18.0.5
@angular/cli                    18.0.5
@schematics/angular             18.0.5
rxjs                            7.4.0
typescript                      5.4.5
zone.js                         0.14.6
```

Issues.Title: feat(mat-datepicker): Allow mat-datepicker to be always visible
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

Right now the datepicker shows only up on clicking the toggle button (or implementing some own logic). I'd love the picker to **always show up** if the bound control is **focused**.

I've tried to achieve this using a custom directive, but there are so many caveats. I'd like the focus to stay in the input and _tabbing_ away to close it. But using the `blur` event doesn't work since selecting a date blurs the control, too.

### Use Case

I want to make users aware of the possibility to just pick a date while keeping the comfort of filling a form by keyboard / tab only.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(mat-datepicker): Allow mat-datepicker to be always visible" (#29301)

Issues.Title: docs-bug(mat-table): Example suggesting to use max-width to set column width is misleading
Issues.Body: ### Documentation Feedback The CSS for this example uses the `max-width` property. However, if you expand the page wide enough, it's clear that this CSS rule doesn't do anything in Chrome, as the computed width of the cell is 72, which is longer than `max-width: 64px` AFAIK, the css `display: table-cell;` does not have a `max-width` property. This CSS should be removed to avoid confusion and a better example of how to configure max-width should be given. ### Affected documentation page https://material.angular.io/components/table/examples#table-http
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "docs-bug(mat-table): Example suggesting to use max-width to set column width is misleading" (#29294)

Issues.Title: docs-bug(@angular/google-maps): map-info-window
Issues.Body:
### Documentation Feedback

There is an error in the map info window doc. It has  #marker="marker" which should be #marker="mapAdvancedMarker" as below.

<google-map
  height="400px"
  width="750px"
  [center]="center"
  [zoom]="zoom"
  (mapClick)="addMarker($event)">
    @for (position of markerPositions; track position) {
      <map-advanced-marker
        #marker="mapAdvancedMarker"
        [position]="position"
        (mapClick)="openInfoWindow(marker)" />
    }
    <map-info-window>Info Window content</map-info-window>
</google-map>

### Affected documentation page

https://github.com/angular/components/blob/main/src/google-maps/map-info-window/README.md
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "docs-bug(@angular/google-maps): map-info-window" (#29293)
